    Interpretation of Linear Regression Models with Abundance-Based Constraints Limitations of lmABC

Interpretation of Linear Regression Models with Abundance-Based Constraints

Source: vignettes/introduction.Rmd
introduction.Rmd
library(lmabc)

Motivation: inequitable interpretation

The inequities in traditional baseline-encoded linear regression are easy to see with model output in R. Let’s look at an example with some simulated data:

summary(lm(y ~ age + race + age:race, df))
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = y ~ age + race + age:race, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -2.70151 -0.52766  0.02578  0.70575  1.99115 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)    1.24517    0.24523   5.077 9.01e-07 ***
#> age            1.95761    0.04655  42.053  < 2e-16 ***
#> raceAsian      2.04445    0.53990   3.787 0.000204 ***
#> raceHisp      -2.05399    0.57003  -3.603 0.000400 ***
#> raceNHB        0.66642    0.49206   1.354 0.177219    
#> age:raceAsian  0.13343    0.09424   1.416 0.158453    
#> age:raceHisp   0.77194    0.10287   7.504 2.24e-12 ***
#> age:raceNHB   -0.12486    0.09487  -1.316 0.189743    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 0.9836 on 192 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9566, Adjusted R-squared:  0.955 
#> F-statistic:   604 on 7 and 192 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

The output does not explicitly note that the continuous effect (age) is specific to the NHW race group and not a global effect for the population; similarly, the age:Hisp and age:NHB effects do not actually correspond to the race-specific slopes, but rather the difference between the NHW-specific slope and the race-specific slopes for Hispanic and NH Black individuals, respectively.

Furthermore, regularization methods like variable selection would unfairly shrink coefficients toward the NHW-specific effect. The (racial) asymmetry is clear, and model-based inferences may differ depending on the choice of baseline.

Together, we see that the default “baseline” method of linear regression creates inequities in interpretation and analysis. We believe it is important to deploy a more fair strategy, such as linear regression with abundance-based constraints.

Our solution: abundance-based constraints

In the corresponding paper to this R package, we explain in great depth the mathematical properties of our lmABC operation. This vignette will briefly explain model interpretation.

Consider a simple model using the data from the previous section. Now, let’s use lmABC.

fit_no_int <- lmabc(y ~ age + race, df)
summary(fit_no_int)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lmabc(formula = y ~ age + race, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -3.7284 -0.6974  0.0789  0.6990  3.6335 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) 11.61100    0.07997 145.185  < 2e-16 ***
#> age          2.06422    0.03886  53.122  < 2e-16 ***
#> raceNHW     -0.64123    0.07620  -8.415 8.31e-15 ***
#> raceAsian    2.06243    0.22227   9.279  < 2e-16 ***
#> raceHisp     1.33443    0.18366   7.266 8.70e-12 ***
#> raceNHB     -0.57022    0.16006  -3.562 0.000462 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 1.131 on 195 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9417, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9405 
#> F-statistic:   787 on 4 and 195 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

In this new model output, age corresponds to the global effect, and the other slopes modify the global effect. For instance, being in the NHW category shifts the intercept by -0.641 units in \(y\) compared to the population as a whole.

We can add interaction terms.

fit_int <- lmabc(y ~ age + race + age:race, df)
summary(fit_int)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lmabc(formula = y ~ age + race + age:race, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -2.70151 -0.52766  0.02578  0.70575  1.99115 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   11.56243    0.06989 165.434  < 2e-16 ***
#> age            2.07149    0.03428  60.435  < 2e-16 ***
#> raceNHW       -0.60478    0.06650  -9.094  < 2e-16 ***
#> raceAsian      2.10166    0.19469  10.795  < 2e-16 ***
#> raceHisp       1.17114    0.16132   7.260 9.40e-12 ***
#> raceNHB       -0.55782    0.13964  -3.995 9.22e-05 ***
#> age:raceNHW   -0.11388    0.03266  -3.487 0.000605 ***
#> age:raceAsian  0.01955    0.07966   0.245 0.806434    
#> age:raceHisp   0.65806    0.08305   7.924 1.82e-13 ***
#> age:raceNHB   -0.23874    0.07263  -3.287 0.001204 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 0.9836 on 192 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9566, Adjusted R-squared:  0.955 
#> F-statistic:   604 on 7 and 192 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

Here, the interaction terms modify the coefficient of age, which is now the global effect of age on \(y\).

Crucially, the model itself is the same as the traditional baseline-encoded linear regression model. Thus, all properties of the model—residuals, R-squared, information for diagnostics—remain the same. lmABC just computes a different, fairer expression of the model than lm provides.

The lmABC package includes implementations for many common methods: summary, print, plot, predict, logLik, vcov, and more. And we don’t just have the abundance-based constraints version of lm—check out glmABC, too!
